I mean, YMMV. Here's Nomura.

Mouselet Yes; it's an absolutely fundamental problem
BE11:18am

Intel held a call after the market close on Wednesday following various articles in the media stating that x86-based chipsets produced over the past decade may feature a design flaw that could compromise security at the hardware level. Intel has stated that the issue is only confined to its processors, and that it has embarked on an industry-wide collaboration with AMD/ARM, OS providers, and OEMs to implement mitigations within the next few weeks. We believe the impact to Intel’s financials and long-term market share is minimal.

A. M. @Shinshin: it might also mean that they'll need to re-design their future chips.
Mouselet (and a work of genius, in the classic way that you could lead a reasonable compsci interview candidate to it with three questions but it took a long time for lots of clever people to notice it in the first place)
Mouselet Javascript can't call into the kernel in such a way as to get the kernel to do anything. What it can do is read kernel memory slowly.
11:19 am
BE11:19am

Genuinely. This is all it is. It's speaking to Intel and believing what they say. El Reg's breakdown of the Intel press release is so much better in terms of analysis it's genuinely a bit shocking.

BE11:20am

The security threat is rooted in a technology featured in most modern-day processors. Although the initial report of a security vulnerability from online IT journal The Register focused on x86-based Intel CPUs, Intel has emphasized that the problem is not specific to its processors. Intel added that the first researchers to discover the issue were from the Google Project Zero team. According to a blog postpublished today by Google researchers, the security threat surrounds “speculative execution,” a technique incorporated in most modern CPUs as a way to optimize workloads. The proposed attack is a side-channel analysis exploit, which would allow the attacker to gain access to privileged memory and circumvent privilege levels without being able to modify its contents.

PM11:20am

hmm

Boncoeur @mouselet: yeah but it can steal passwords
11:20 am
PM11:20am

YMMV * Your mileage may vary

Mouselet Which is in itself a bit of a problem because 'kernel memory' quite often means 'all the memory in the system', particularly on hypervisor systems which map all physical memory into the address map
Mouselet yes, it can steal passwords, it can steal SSH keys, it can steal private keys, it can steal anything in the system. That's the nature of a memory-reading exploit.
BE11:21am

According to Intel, the impact on processor performance will be minimal on average. Mgmt. established that the issue is not exclusive to its datacenter or PC clients, and that the performance degradation will depend on the size of the workload. In particular, Intel stated that user space workloads could see 0%-2% decline in performance, while the performance of synthetic workloads could potentially be curbed by over 30%, although an “outlier case.” We see low average impact on x86 CPU performance and highlight commentary by Intel that the threat is not a result of product error and that mitigations will be available to customers over the next few weeks.
• We don’t expect this design flaw to impact market share dynamics between Intel and AMD. As such, our estimates are unchanged at $0.73 in the March quarter, $3.35 in 2018 and $3.64 in 2019.

BE11:21am

And Barclays.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

INTC and AMD clearly disagree about the scope of the side channel vulnerability with INTC referencing that the issue is more industry wide and AMD sighting the issue as more of an INTC architectural flaw.

Mouselet It relies on precision timing, but it turns out that 'do things quickly' can be repurposed as 'precision timing' quite readily, particularly if you can get things to run in parallel
Boncoeur Ok, javascript cant explicitly call into kernel, I recant that.
BE11:22am

Reality likely lies somewhere in between with the performance degradation ....

Mouselet I don't think GPUs perform speculative execution of quite the same kind - it is an expensive thing to build the hardware for and GPUs reckon that adding 128 more copies of smaller hardware is a better use of silicon
BE11:23am

likely at the lower end if not below

11:23 am
BE11:23am

the 30% range that was suggested for most workloads. Obviously a negative for Intel, but flaws in processor architectures happen from time to time and ultimately get resolved with little financial impact or share shift. We would also highlight that Intel’s unique architecture likely also allowed for unique benefits so this flaw only eats into those gains. What we know for sure is that INTC maintains there will be no financial impact, which is somewhat comforting given the drastic stock reaction throughout the market yesterday and that the company believes there will be no change in their acceptance of the product. Net net, though this specific exploit is new, these types of issues come to the forefront historically for many architectures, and we believe this time it should be no different, with the applicable fixes ushered in as quickly as possible making the move yesterday appear overdone to us.

We do not expect a material impact to Intel’s financials, sales or share position. While Intel's stock had already been impacted on the media reports during yesterday’s trading session, we do not anticipate any material impact to Intel's sales going forward, nor do we expect any meaningful share shift as a result of this issue. Moreover, Intel’s representatives on the call stated clearly that they do not expect Intel to be impacted financially from the security issue (i.e. Intel not likely to take any charges as its processors are performing to specification).

Group sales -0.8% over the 17 weeks to 30 December, driven by LFL -1.8% (GSe +1.1%, LFL +0.8%). The early weeks of the quarter were disappointing. Following promotional action, LFL in the 6 week Christmas period +1.2%; however the first week of the post-Christmas sale was below expectations despite further mark-down investment. The mid-point of guidance (c.€60mn) implies -27% downside risk to consensus FY18E PBT, which, all else equal, would imply 3.9p consensus EPS, -37% yoy. Sell.

This isn’t a retailing or macro issue, this is all about Debenhams; the tightening in consumer spending and fx pressure is tough enough to leave the more challenged retailers facing margin decline and cost growth, which they are unable to mitigate and trade out of; we believe the consumer proposition is simply not compelling enough. Opportunities for recovery in the sector centre on market share leaders with strong balance sheets, growth comes from our e-commerce and structural growth picks, which continue to flourish, but Debenhams fits into neither camp. We downgrade forecasts and expect the dividend to be cut while Debenhams starts to accelerate its investment plans.

The momentum consistently reported by Sopheon since 2H15 continues, with today’s trading update reporting FY17 outperformance in all of revenue, EBITDA and pre tax profit. Earnings quality is also improved by growth in recurring revenue, derived from both increased maintenance revenue and continuing development of the SaaS revenue streams. Following on from the December loan stock conversion, which further strengthened the balance sheet and introduced an increased number of shares which can potentially ease liquidity constraints, strategic measures to deliver a valuation more appropriate to the Megabuyte Accounting and Enterprise software peer group (at 16.8x EV/EBITDA and 26x P/E) are all in place and we look forward to a strong year for Sopheon. We suspend forecasts pending clarity of the extent of the outperformance, and look forward to prelims on 22 March. Target of a minimum of 620p reiterated.

EverydayBloke Debs pays minimal rent anyway. It was used as the bait for new shopping centres where the smaller retailers ended up footing higher rental bills instead. This worked well prior to 2010, but now the pressure is being applied to smaller retailers within shopping malls who aren't tied into 50 year leases like Debs. This, of course, why debs took such long leases. Not that this helps their situation as a failing business. Just some background. Sorin Capital did some research on this in the US but it applies in the UK too.

11:48 am
BE11:49am

The decision to spend less on R&D could increase our 2018 EBITDA forecast by c40%; however,
assuming this R&D was previously going to be invested productively, the offset could be lower future growth.
The cautious view on R&D spend implies significant delays on the US generic Advair application are likely. Vectura’s partner Hikma is due to provide an update this quarter on the dispute with FDA with relation to the need for another clinical trial for the US generic Advair program. Ahead of the outcome of this FDA dispute being announced, we believe the market could interpret Vectura’s decision to cut back on 2018 R&D as indicating that a bullish scenario of Hikma winning the FDA appeal looks improbable, with a significant delay looking far more likely, which is what we already model, with no generic launch until the end of 2019.
Overall, we see a more conservative approach on R&D spend as a positive, but we also see this as
suggestive that progress on US generic Advair will likely be slow and, hence, overall, we don’t expect the company to be fully rewarded for the significant EBITDA uplift that the lower R&D spend will drive, and we also see some offset from worse economics on VR647 and discontinuation of the Mundi triple

I guess it can be spun both ways. Here's Panmure.

11:50 am
BE11:51am

The change in strategy makes sense given the delay launch of VR315 which commenced with the receipt of the CRL by Hikma in mid-2017. With the lower R&D spend Vectura should remain cash generative even without the launch of VR315 and it significantly reduces the risk of the business model. Vectura has been successful with the partnering approach both historically and recently, with new deals signed in with Dynavax and Sandoz in the last 6 months. We believe that the revised strategy, creates a lower risk opportunity in the near term.
